As long as the forces of natural selection and mutation continue to shape our genetic makeup, it is likely that humans will continue to evolve in the future. However, it is difficult to predict exactly how this evolution will occur or what traits will become more or less advantageous over time. 

One factor that may shape human evolution in the future is advances in technology and medicine. For example, genetic engineering and gene editing technologies may allow humans to intentionally modify their genetic makeup, potentially leading to new kinds of natural selection, as certain genetically modified traits may be more or less advantageous depending on the environmental context.

Moreover, factors such as population growth, migration, and changes in the environment can also exert selective pressures on human evolution. For example, changes in climate or food availability could lead to adaptations in human physiology or metabolism to better survive in new environments. 

Therefore, the direction of human evolution is difficult to predict, but it is clear that our genetic makeup will continue to change over time in response to the pressures and challenges we face as a species.
